request_pathways.name: Medical Records Request form (Bath Community Physicians Group)
Fax submission to Bath Community Physicians Group

access_pathway.primary_pathway_description: A single generic release-of-information form designed for inter-provider transfers that patients must adapt for self-access by marking 'Send' and filling in their own contact information as the recipient.

red_flags: Witness signature required — not mandated by HIPAA for patient access requests
Requests last four digits of Social Security Number on a faxable form
Multiple OCR errors in text layer make document inaccessible to screen readers
bright_spots: Separate consent checkbox for alcohol/drug abuse and psychiatric records (proper 42 CFR Part 2 practice)
Includes option for patient to request a copy of their signed authorization

findability.rationale: Level 4: Form is linked from the Patient Resources → Forms page and found via simple web search; reachable in 2-3 clicks from homepage.

technical_accessibility.rationale: Level 2: Primarily a paper workflow — form is a scanned image with no functional fillable fields, requiring print and handwrite; fax number is listed in the header but submission instructions are absent.

content_design.rationale: Level 3: Adequate one-page layout with logical flow, but notable problems including OCR errors degrading readability, no submission instructions, pre-filled 'CONTINUATION OF CARE' reason with unclear editability, and no guidance text.

patient_centeredness.rationale: Level 2: Patient self-access is not addressed — the Send/Receive structure is designed for inter-provider transfers, with no mention of patient access rights, no date range field, and no delivery format options.

compliance.rationale: Level 3: Witness requirement goes beyond what HIPAA mandates for patient access; partial SSN collection raises privacy concerns; no fee disclosure or rights language — though sensitive-records consent is properly separated.

overall.summary: Bath Community Hospital provides a findable but minimally functional paper-based ROI form that was not designed for patient self-access, with a witness barrier and poor digital accessibility.
